name: 65XEP / 65XEM
keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard, 57 keys + 5 function keys (Help, Start, Select, Option, Reset)
colors: Monochrome green (65XEP), 16 colors with 15 intensity level each (65XEM)
ports: Composite video output, Cardridge port, Expansion port, SIO peripheral port (tape, disk, printer, modem), 2 x joystick connectors
power: Built-in poxer supply unit (65XEP), external power supply unit - 1A, 5v cc (65XEM)
description:
The 65XEP was the first portable computer Atari designed. It was first exhibited in 1985, at the CES show. With the 65XEP, Atari intended to compete with the Commodore SX-64

It was actually a portable version of the Atari 65XE including a 3.5" 360 KB disk drive, a 5" green CRT and a battery pack.
The price was fixed at less than $400, but Atari never released this machine. Apparently only one prototype was built.

At the same time, Atari announced a second variation of the 65XE, the 65XEM (for XE Music). This version featured a new powerful polyphonic sound chip called AMY with 8 independent sound voices and 64 oscillators. It was able to synthesize voice and any musical instrument sound much better than the Commodore 64's SID chip. 
However, the AMY chip never reached production, so the 65XEM never passed the prototype stage either.

Thanks to Cyberroach for the picture.
_______________________

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORIGINAL ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The history of the Galaksija started with a magazine article - called "Raèunara u vašoj kuæi" (computers in your home) by Dejan Ristanoviæ. This magazine was the first issue of the magazine series called later "Raèunara". This first issue included an article about the do-if-yourself computer "Galaksija" written by Voja Antonic. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source : <a href="http://www.homecomputer.de/" target="_blank">HomeComputerMuseum.de</a></font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - SYSTEM IN SPACE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JULY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OFFICIAL FLYER (VERSO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mainbyte.com" target="_blank">www.mainbyte.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The high performance Computer System for practice-oriented applications." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #4 </strong></font><br><blockquote>In June 1983, IBM was still seeking independant programmers.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666" The envelope please.<br> There's an acceptance letter inside. And a check that could have your name on it. (If we select your program, that is.)<br> But remember. We pick our winners carefully... </font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 6000 MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> WE HAVE A NEW APPROACH TO DISTRIBUTED PROCESSING THAT WORKS <br><br> Already implemented are electronic mail, word processing, complete cost accounting with inventory control and more. The secret is a new technology called Functionally Structured Distribution (FSD). At last, a system to organize and manage distributed processing applications that is really up and running. FSD technology is especially applicable to installa­tions that require:<br> • Unlimited expandability supporting extremely large data bases and terminals in many cities.<br> • User-friendly software easily programmed in high level languages (COBOL, FORTRAN, and BASIC)<br> • System reliability (due to distributed hardware) while maintaining multiple levels of data security.<br> • Compatibility with existing mainframes and networks (including the Bell System). <br><br> We are presently installing Billings 6000 Computer Systems which take full advantage of distributed processing utilizing FSD technology. The 6000 Computer supports multiple hard disk drives with capacities of up to 64 Mbytes (formatted), streaming tapes for backup, auto-dial modems (2400 baud synchronous) for communications, and flexible disk drives for smaller installations.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #5</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was used to promote the educative potential of the TO-7/70. This poor student is studying economic politics... <br><br> As usual, no cables are shown... the tape recorder is thus useless... Will someone tell him ?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, FEB 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GENEVA AD, OCT. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-170 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> I LEARN AT SCHOOL</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert for the new model, dated april 1986. <br><br> "I learn at school, I rock at home"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>A pretty secretary, a clean office with nice colours, and a computer working without any printer, cables, disks... Does it really sound realistic to you ?!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACCOUNTING SYSTEMS A5 AND A7</strong></font><br><blockquote>Systems A5 and A7, presented in 1974, contributing significantly to shifting the focus towards the supply Olivetti computer. These machines have the characteristics of a real computer, and hence a discontinuity from the previous accounting and billing are mainly based on mechanical technology. The new machines meet the favor of the European market and in 1975 the Swiss magazine Information, which specializes in computer and office products, a dedicated their cover.<p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.storiaolivetti.it" target="_blank">http://www.storiaolivetti.it</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The amazing TI-99/4A.<br> A computer for 1800fr"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Chuck Hunkle, who worked at MSI in 1977-79, kindly sent us the complete 1978 MSI catalog. All the pages are shown in the following pictures.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is nearly a stupid scan ! <br><br> The young boy says : ''In 1984, my father bought me a MO-5" <br> And on his desk is a 1998 calendar... <br><br> They meant that if you bought the MO-5 then (the advert is from 1984), you would be rich and clever 14 years later (in 1998). Ha ha ha !! <br><br> It's funny to see how they tried to represent an office and a town of 1998. I really love this one !  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SIL'Z III</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice fish-eye picture of a Sil'z III illustrating a 1982 article about Technologic Revolution in the french mag TeleSoft.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANCO BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

item.description: Indus GT|||5''/14 disk-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> INDUS GT</strong></font><br><strong>> 5''/14 disk-drive</strong><br><blockquote>The Indus GT Double Density Drive is considered by many the best floppy drive available for the 8-bit Atari's with its digital readouts and smoke plexi cover.</blockquote>

Astra 2001 FD unit|||Dual 5.25|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ASTRA 2001 FD UNIT</strong></font><br><strong>> Dual 5.25</strong><br><blockquote>Dual 5.25" FDD unit using single side, single or double density floppy drives </blockquote>

Percom disc drive|||Advert|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PERCOM DISC DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> Advert</strong><br><blockquote>March 1983 Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The Percom Data AT-88 offers 88 Kbytes (formatted) in single-density, with plug-in ease of attachment to your Atari. The AT-88 has integral power supply, "no-patch" to Atari DOS and critical constant speed regulation.<br> Take advantage of this low introductory price of $488... </font> </blockquote>

Corvus Systems hard-drive|||10Mb hard-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CORVUS SYSTEMS HARD-DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> 10Mb hard-drive</strong><br><blockquote>This is a 10Mb hard-drive. With up to 8 multiplexers with 8 ports each it's possible to connect up to 64 Atari 800's up to a single 10 or even 20 megabyte Atari system. Still in use Today at the Fordham Prepatory School in the Bronx, NY is a 64 Atari 800 computer network hooked up to a single Corvus Hard drive system !  <br><br> The Corvus hard disk system also sported a unique and innovative back-up system called "The Corvus Mirror" which was a VCR interface system that allowed you to plug a standard Video Cassette Recorder (VCR) up to the Corvus Hard Drive System to save back-ups of the hard disk onto actual Video Tapes!!!</blockquote>

Touch Tablet||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> TOUCH TABLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>The touch tablet was the best tool for drawing and painting. It shipped with the AtariArtist cartridge.</blockquote>

emulator.name: The Atari 800 Emulator for the Mac
Atari++
emulator.description: Unix based emulator of the Atari eight bit computers, namely the Atari 400 and 800, the Atari 400XL, 800XL and 130XE, and the Atari 5200 game console

emulator.name: Atari800
emulator.description: Atari800 is an Atari 800, 800XL, 130XE and 5200 emulator for Unix, Amiga, MS-DOS, Atari TT/Falcon, SDL and WinCE
